description:
Add a mod function which 'wraps' coordinates so they stay between 0 and 1.
Without the mod, ((ccoord[0]-x0)/(x1-x0)) and others are not in the interval
[0.,1.] if 'center' is used.
title: Correct coordinate problem when 'center' is used in plots.

pullrequest.title: Correct coordinate problem when 'center' is used in plots.

content.raw:
To give people a better idea why this is necessary, here is the result of annotate_halos on a ProjectionPlot which was drawn with the option `center=([0,0,0],"Mpc")`

![projection_halo_before.png](https://bitbucket.org/repo/BXbAb/images/2951585864-projection_halo_before.png)

And here is with the fix:

![projection_halo_after.png](https://bitbucket.org/repo/BXbAb/images/237239712-projection_halo_after.png)
content.html:
To give people a better idea why this is necessary, here is the result of annotate_halos on a ProjectionPlot which was drawn with the option center=([0,0,0],"Mpc")

content.raw: Forgive the naive question, but will this work correctly if the domain is not [0, 1]?  Some frontends have different domain sizes, at least in `code_length`.
content.html: Forgive the naive question, but will this work correctly if the domain is not [0, 1]? Some frontends have different domain sizes, at least in code_length.

pullrequest.title: Correct coordinate problem when 'center' is used in plots.

content.raw:
If you could send me a test case to try I could look and see.

My initial reaction is yes though since the point of (ccoord[0]-x0)/(x1-x0) and friends seems to be to normalize the coordinates. They are then multiplied by a new range. This logic only works if the normalization length is 1.
content.html:
If you could send me a test case to try I could look and see.

My initial reaction is yes though since the point of (ccoord[0]-x0)/(x1-x0) and friends seems to be to normalize the coordinates. They are then multiplied by a new range. This logic only works if the normalization length is 1.

pullrequest.title: Correct coordinate problem when 'center' is used in plots.

content.raw:
I think this data should work: http://yt-project.org/data/rockstar_halos.tar.gz

This is just a rockstar halo catalog, but since Rockstar's code_length is "Mpccm/h", the domain is [0, 128] in code_length.  You can probably do something like the following for testing: http://paste.yt-project.org/show/6980/
content.html:

pullrequest.title: Correct coordinate problem when 'center' is used in plots.

content.raw:
Okay, so once I draw halos and numbers in black, I get:

![halos_0.0.bin_Particle_x_particle_mass_nocenter_halos_withfix.png](https://bitbucket.org/repo/BXbAb/images/4108838220-halos_0.0.bin_Particle_x_particle_mass_nocenter_halos_withfix.png)

Testing this with center=([10,10,0],'Mpc') I get

![halos_0.0.bin_Particle_x_particle_mass_center_halos_withfix.png](https://bitbucket.org/repo/BXbAb/images/682632394-halos_0.0.bin_Particle_x_particle_mass_center_halos_withfix.png)

which is wonky..
Just to test, I tried center without the fix, and I get:

![halos_0.0.bin_Particle_x_particle_mass_center_halos_nofix.png](https://bitbucket.org/repo/BXbAb/images/1209591840-halos_0.0.bin_Particle_x_particle_mass_center_halos_nofix.png)

So there's a problem with the ParticleProjectionPlot's logic as well when 'center' is used.

content.raw: I think this makes sense since in this case you would want to take the mod with whatever `ds.domain_width` is instead of always 1.0.  I can't tell if this function has access to the value of the domain width.  If not, perhaps the function calling this does and it can be passed in.
content.html: I think this makes sense since in this case you would want to take the mod with whatever ds.domain_width is instead of always 1.0. I can't tell if this function has access to the value of the domain width. If not, perhaps the function calling this does and it can be passed in.

content.raw: The 1.0s in the mod statements need to be replaced with the correct values in`plot.data.ds.domain_width`.  This will make the callback work with datasets where the domain is not [0, 1].

pullrequest.title: Correct coordinate problem when 'center' is used in plots.

content.raw:
So I looked at this and I think Matt's correct to use `1.0` in the call to `np.mod`. The reason we had issues with your test script is that the `HalosCallback` was implicitly assuming the plot coordinates are in code units (i.e. the halo positions are converted to code units, *not* the plot units). This particular plot has units of Mpc, while the code units were Mpc/h. So there was a factor of little h that wasn't being accounted for.

The fix was to get rid of that assumption and convert the halo positions to the units of the plot.

I committed a fix for this which Matt should be pushing to this pull request shortly.
content.html:
So I looked at this and I think Matt's correct to use 1.0 in the call to np.mod. The reason we had issues with your test script is that the HalosCallback was implicitly assuming the plot coordinates are in code units (i.e. the halo positions are converted to code units, not the plot units). This particular plot has units of Mpc, while the code units were Mpc/h. So there was a factor of little h that wasn't being accounted for.

The fix was to get rid of that assumption and convert the halo positions to the units of the plot.

I committed a fix for this which Matt should be pushing to this pull request shortly.

pullrequest.title: Correct coordinate problem when 'center' is used in plots.

content.html: This should be ready to go in now, I believe the issues with domains that have non-unit dimensions is fixed.
